trade practices act 1974 (cth), ss. 45 , 45a, 80 . the applicant and respondent companies were three sydney commercial radio broadcasting stations which were competing for increased maket shares of the sydney radio listening audience. the applicant company, radio 2ue sydney pty. ltd. (2ue), had operated the am station 2ue for some years. the first respondent, stereo f.m. pty. ltd. (2mmm), which operated the fm station 2mmm, and the second respondent 2day-fm (2day), which operated the fm station 2day, had both commenced broadcasting in or about august 1980. the first and second respondents produced a combined sydney fm rate card (the combined card) aimed at attracting advertisers to place advertising with both 2mmm and 2day and was expressed to be effective from 1st december, 1981. evidence showed that each respondent fixed and charged its own advertising rates independently of the other and was free to change its rates whenever it wished.

whether conduct likely to cause substantial loss

trade practices act 1974 (cth), s. 45d (1). the appellant, tillmanns butcheries pty. ltd. ("tillmanns"), was a wholesale and retail butcher carrying on business in canberra and queanbeyan. the first-named respondent, the australasian meat industry employees' union ("the union") was an organization of employees including employees of wholesale and retail butchers and employees in abattoirs. the third, fifth, sixth and seventh respondents were the president, secretary and two organizers of the union respectively. in december 1977 two of the respondents entered tillmannss' shop in queanbeyan and asked to see the employees. the request was refused by tillmanns' managing director because it was neither smoko nor lunchtime. the union retaliated by imposing a black ban upon tillmanns' shops. at that time canberra abattoir pty. ltd. ("canberra abattoir"), a company which conducted an abattoir in the australian capital territory, held for tillmanns thirty-two cattle awaiting slaughter and the carcasses of twenty head of cattle and seventeen pigs. as a result of the black ban by the union the live cattle were not slaughtered for some weeks and the carcasses were released to tillmanns only about a week later to avoid deterioration. the appellant instituted an action in the federal court of australia seeking an injunction and damages under ss. 80 and 82 in relation to s. 45d of the trade practices act 1974 ("the act ") alleging that the respondents acted in concert to prevent supplies of meat to tillmanns in breach of s. 45d of the act . the trial judge declined to find that the respondents' conduct had the relevant effect and refused to award damages or to grant an injunction. he stated in his judgment, inter alia, that the plaintiff (appellant) was not entitled to argue that the conduct complained of would be likely to cause substantial loss where the means of proving whether in fact it did cause substantial loss were in its power. the appellant appealed to the full court of the federal court of australia against this judgment claiming that an injunction should have been ordered.  held: per curiam

the appeal against the first, third, fifth, sixth and seventh respondents should be upheld, the cross appeal of those respondents should be dismissed and the appellant should be granted injunctive relief against the above-named respondents because: (1) the appellant was entitled to seek relief on the ground that the relevant conduct of the respondents, if continued, would or would be likely to have the effect of causing substantial loss or damage to the appellant's business.
requirement as condition of supply of radio service that members acquire petrol directly or indirectly from a second person

co-operation act, 1923 (n.s.w.), ss. 9, 60, 77, 82, reg. 32 (2c). the applicant in these proceedings sought the imposition of a penalty on the respondent under s. 76 of the trade practices act 1974 (the act) in respect of alleged breaches of s. 47 (1) of the act occuring before 1st july, 1977. it also applied under s. 80 for an injunction against the respondent in respect of conduct occuring since that date.  the respondent, legion cabs (trading) co-operative society ltd., is incorporated as a trading society under the co-operation act, 1923 (n.s.w.). the respondent has a number of members, the majority of whom are owner-members. these members own vehicles licensed to operate as taxis in sydney. the main activity of the respondent is to provide a radio service for its members so that communication can be maintained with the drivers. the respondent also operated, at the relevant time, two service stations where members could obtain petrol.
federal court of australia act 1976 , ss. 17 , 50

european economic community treaty, art. 86. by a letter of agreement dated 7th december, 1977, ansett transport industries ltd. (ansett industries) offered to purchase for cash, upon the terms contained in the letter, all the issued shares in the capital of avis rent-a-car system pty. ltd. (avis). the shares were held by shellbank holdings pty. ltd. and sixty martin place pty. ltd. (the vendors). in the same letter of agreement, the vendors signified their acceptance of the offer subject to the approval of the minister for transport. by letter dated 13th december, 1977, avis formally notified the minister for transport of the acquisition by ansett industries of all the issued shares in the capital of avis and sought his written confirmation of the verbal approval previously given that the authority under the airports (business concessions) act 1959 held by avis and dated 30th june, 1969, would not be determined "by reason of the change in ownership or control of avis" resulting from the transaction. by letter dated 14th december, 1977, ansett industries notified the minister for transport of the purchase, advised him that the purchaser would be ansett transport industries (operations) pty. ltd. (ansett operations), a wholly-owned subsidiary of ansett industries, and sought his approval to the "substantial ownership" change in avis shareholding to enable the airport franchise to continue in operation until its expiry on 30th june, 1979.  in announcing the agreement, ansett industries claimed that avis was "by far the major car rental organization in australia" and had "an exclusive car rental franchise at all commonwealth airports, thirty-three local ownership airports and many city outlets throughout australia".
